target_title: Added games Regicide, Syndicate, Dead Center, Foursquare, The Emissary and Loot the Loop

note.body:
- I noticed one game lost condition that is not detected yet: you have no notes, the top card is not a trinket, and the 2nd card is hidden.

- the hints look helpful; I noticed that sometimes you get a hint to explore with the second card even when it is face down. I think the deck split change caused some of the hints to break as they now check a wrong card. And maybe the hints could consistently use either the expression "exploration slot" or "exploration area", not both?

- The deck split made it easier to play. I think that it is difficult to set the spacing so that it looks good on all window sizes though. Currently the top card might even fully cover the second card in a narrow window. Treize is simpler in that it has normal slots. In my opinion it might be better to leave out the deck split after all and show 10, 12 (maybe a compromise between making it easy to count and showing more information), or 15 deck cards, but it's up to you of course.

I don't know how difficult it would be to do or whether the changes would be accepted, but eventually it could be better to make the changes to board drawing code. I noticed that the deck contracting in a narrow window is due to the game engine computing space for all the cards in the deck, even though only 10 are shown. I looked at the code, and implementing the fix mentioned here might fix it: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/aisleriot/-/blob/master/src/board-noclutter.c#L604. It probably wouldn't be a one line change though. Also I noticed there is a scheme function `set-slot-x-expansion!` (Ten Across uses the corresponding `set-slot-y-expansion!`) that could be used to add more space between the deck cards, but that currently would have no effect because of the first mentioned issue.

For the second presentation issue -- to display more than 10 cards while keeping it easy to count cards -- I think it would be ideal to be able to call `(set-slot-group-size! slot-id 5)` or do something similar, to tell the board drawing code to leave some extra space after every fifth card (EDIT: I mean that the 5th and 6th cards would overlap less than the nth and (n+1)th cards do in general, similarly the 10th and 11th etc.) I don't know whether this change would be feasible or acceptable.

target_title: Added games Regicide, Syndicate, Dead Center, Foursquare, The Emissary and Loot the Loop

note.body:
I played the rest of the games too. I wrote down some problems I noticed and ideas for possible improvements. I hope some of this helps.


**The Emissary**

The score described in the manual is not being calculated (in the end, after winning, "Score: 0").

The current target score and the total score could be shown separately. Having the total score in the lower right corner would be my expectation after playing other Aisleriot games.

Rules: "Add that ruler face up beneath your advisors" -- it's added on top of the advisors

Discard pile is not cleared after winning a kingdom.

You can only activate one ability (= use one advisor) at once. Then the game automatically starts a debate. The rules suggest you can activate any number of abilities at once before any debate.

Status message: "Use an ability or start the debate" -> "[...] **a** debate"?

The selected ruler pile (with two cards) overlaps slightly with the piles in the middle row -- it would be good to add a bit of empty space between (maybe 1/4 card height (see for example Triple Peaks for how to do that))

If you play a Spade advisor when there is only one ruler left, you are stuck -- the status bar reads "Select a new ruler" and the game waits for you to choose one, but there are no valid choices; instead, make spade advisors no-op when there is just one ruler.

The manual says: "If you run out of cards in the draw pile, shuffle the discard pile and continue using it." -- this is not implemented. Currently, if the draw pile gets empty, the game is lost. Notice that the draw pile might get empty also after playing a club or diamond advisor. In those cases too, the discard pile could be flipped over on to stock, reshuffled, and then dealing into hand would continue if it was not finished.

It would be nice if the cards in hand were ordered by suit and rank. That would make it harder to see what you get when you draw more cards though, so I'm not sure about this.

The game could be "dealable", that is, it could implement the "dealable feature". do-deal-next-cards could deal a card from deck to discard; then the player could deal also with Ctrl+D or the deal button. This would also help to see when it is possible to flip a card to discard, because the deal button would change color when you can deal.

Cards in discard could be made non-draggable since they cannot be dropped anywhere (like cards in 'scored' and 'rulers' cannot be dragged)

button-clicked returns #t when mode is m-swap-ruler, and the current ruler is clicked, although game state doesn't change

Allow playing advisors by clicking or double-clicking?


**Foursquare**

Could I just click a slot to place the current draw card -- no dragging?

An undo/redo history state is being saved on every click -- #t should be returned when game state changes, and #f when not.

State variables are not restored after undo -- they should be defined with 'def-save-var' instead of 'define'. Some state variables could be removed too. Then there would be no need to update them. Empty slots and piles with top card face down could be counted whenever needed, it's not a heavy operation.

The game freezes when you lose and click New Game or Restart in the dialogue that opens. It's because the state variables are not assigned new values in new-game -- if they indicate a game-over state, the engine will try to start a new game endlessly.

You lose if the pile gets empty or there are >4 face-down piles. It might be better if the game ended already when you cannot place a card without it resulting in >4 face-down piles. That is what the manual says. That way the player wouldn't have to check all possible placements of a draw card to conclude that the game is over.

The rules say: "You may play the [draw] card either:
1. As the first card of a new pile, vertically or horizontally adjacent to an existing pile [...]"

-- however, currently you can place the card as the first card of a new pile on any slot -- adjacency is not required. (Also it is not mentioned where the first draw card can be placed (anywhere, it seems.))

No need to show score since no scoring.

I don't know but I guess that semicolons should be made translatable.

EDIT: Forgot to mention that moving a card to a slot adds two instances of the card to the slot.

**Syndicate**

Rules say: "To promote a member, move its card to the next rank, adding it either to the higher rank’s members or candidates." -- Currently you can only add it to members, not candidates.

Score not calculated at all, although the manual describes scoring.

Rules say: "You may only promote someone if you can ﬁnd a valid replacement from the candidates below it, which you move up to the members area to replace the promoted card." -- currently you can promote even if you are not going to have a valid replacement. Then the game will end after the promotion. I think better to call game over already when nothing can be promoted and replaced. That way the player wouldn't have to check all possible promotions to conclude that the game is over. (Also, currently you may promote a member to rank 0, which is described as the winning condition, without having a valid replacement. Then game is lost, which is contradictory.)

You get stuck if you sacrifice members (= move them to graveyard) until none of the ranks has three members. The game could for example a. not allow moving to graveyard when just one rank has 3 members, or b. call game-over if none of the ranks has 3 members and you are supposed to promote a card next.

Make status messages translatable.

Clicks might return #t even if they don't change game state.

No reason to have "Syndicate" in the status bar? The game's name is in the window title.

In all games hints would be nice.

target_title: Added games Regicide, Syndicate, Dead Center, Foursquare, The Emissary and Loot the Loop

note.body:
I was unclear on the first point. I think it is enough to give the attack power in the table; no need to repeat it in Setup. What I don't find in the rules is that when you have "recruited" an enemy into your hand, what is it's attack/blocking power then? For example for Jack it's 10/10, not 10/20 as one might guess based on the table of enemy card characteristics.

The problem with drag-and-drop didn't go away. There's an obvious error in the updated code. How to test it: 1. Move one card from hand to staging. 2. Repeat three times: Start to drag that card and drop it back on to staging. 3. Now press undo. Nothing happens. (You must undo 4 times until the card is moved back to hand.)

Also, it's not enough to return #f from button-released. Also `droppable?` must return #f. If `droppable?` returns #t, there will be blue highlighting on the slot over which a card is being hovered, indicating to the player that you can drop the card there (which you cannot do if button-released returns #f). Probably easiest is to make the change just in `droppable?` since button-released calls it.

Note that some of the suggestions I made before, such as regarding deck creation, not shadowing the built-in `modulo` and `remainder` etc., apply to Regicide and other games as well, although I won't repeat them for each game.

note.body:
Best to use the api functions I think. `make-card`, or something like
```
(set-ace-low)
(make-joker-deck)
(shuffle-deck)

(define (face-card? card) (> (get-value card) 10))
(set-cards! deck (filter (negate face-card?) DECK))
(set-cards! killed (filter face-card? DECK))

```

target_title: Added games Regicide, Syndicate, Dead Center, Foursquare, The Emissary and Loot the Loop

note.body:
Hi, I tried Loot the Loop and Dead Center. Pretty fun games. I wrote some observations below. I'll add comments related to specific spots in source code.

**Loot the Loop**

Trinkets cannot be collected even though the rules say that if you land on one facing up
when exploring, it is moved to the score pile and scores one point, like aces.

The game could end automatically also when no cards can be moved. That is, when neither one of the two top cards in the deck is a numeral between 2 and 10, and you have no notes.

You can currently move some cards directly from notes to exploration. Probably not meant to
be that way? The result varies depending on which one of the max three cards in notes you
try to move.

I think showing 10 topmost cards is good because I find it easier to count than for example with 9
or 11 cards. It would help to know at least the 11th and 12th cards though. Then you could tell
whether exploring with a ten results in an immediate game over. Currently you can peek at
the cards beyond the tenth by lifting some top cards, but not if you play in Click to Move
mode. Some ideas how this could be done: display the 11th and 12th cards (or more) separated
horizontally by a little from the 10 topmost cards, perhaps in a partially overlapping extra
slot, similar to how Waste is presented in Treize. If there's enough separation, then it
might still be easy to count. Could be without overlap too. Or, cards 11-20 could be shown
below cards 1-10.

It would be nice to have a bit more separation between the deck cards, or just
between the 1st and 2nd card. Then grabbing the 2nd card would require less precision. It's not a problem for me with a 24 inch 16:9 screen when using full screen, but a bit difficult on a left or right half of the screen with full height. I don't know if it could be done without using overlapping extra slots. Ok as it is anyway, I think.

Could give hints when clicking the hint button, indicating some possible move.

The status message reads "Loot the loop" at all times. Could it be removed? Or maybe it could show how many aces are left or collected, if also trinkets are added to the score pile.

There's a test tool card-monkey.scm in games directory. It found the problem that dragging a
card from notes back to notes saves a duplicate state in undo/redo history. Just return #f
in `droppable?` and `button-released` if the start slot is the end slot.

You may want to run the tool yourself. If you do, it needs a little tweaking and this might
help: [p](/uploads/f282c216e6e67668b5ddea232e2e903e/p). (user-modules-declarative? #f) is added to ensure that def-save-var variables work. For Loot the Loop, skip-obscure-drop-check should be set to #t. The tool will also complain about games that don't give hints. And it's easiest to remove the dealable feature and dealable? from set-lambda before testing. There is no dealing in Loot the Loop or Dead Center.

Would be nice if maximum possible score was mentioned in help. If the trinkets were added to score, I guess you could get 52 - 12 - 1 = 39? One trinket is needed to land on the joker in the end and cannot be
collected.

**Dead Center**

You cannot choose which zombie card to kill when you have two options, even though the rules
say that you can. Would be good if you could choose, especially when the cards have the same
rank, and maybe sometimes in other cases too. Could for example not accept a new card on to
the cabin or reveal more zombies before the player has chosen which card to kill. That way
the chance couldn't go unnoticed.

(Double-/)clicking on a pile adds a history state even if the game state does not
change. Check that #f is returned when nothing changes and #t otherwise.

There is no game-over check for the case where you cannot place the draw card.

Clicking on an empty zombie pile crashes the game.

Would be good to give a hint on request I think, some possible move, even though the status bar already gives advice.

The manual says: "Your score is the number of cards left in the deck", but the score is
actually the number of killed zombies.

note.body:
> Question: Do you know why there's a separate lib? 

lib? You mean the `lib/` subdirectory? That's just code organisation, no shared library is built from aisleriot source code.

> I vaguely remember there was a standalone freecell game — was it for that?

There was, but nowadays `freecell` doesn't even exist anymore except as a `--freecell` argument to `sol` to directly launch aisleriot with freecell game.

target_title: Missing game Hearts which was before standolane game as gnome hearts

note.body: Hearts is a multi-player game; aiseriot only supports single-player solitaires. AFAIK the gnome-hearts source code isn't available anymore on gitlab.gnome.org, but maybe someone has archived it somewhere else.

target_title: Port to gtk4 and libadwaita

note.body:
I started digging into this. It's going to be quite a journey — there's a ton of code here from the GTK2 era that is just not needed by gtk4, or is wildly different. This is going to end up more of a rewrite in large sections than a straight port.

I pushed a simple MR to master that just cleaned up some warnings to make it a bit easier to see what's going on, but it won't really be possible to do the port in place without disabling / rewriting chunks of it. I'll start a branch to start the gtk3 modernization, but any thoughts on how best to land this? I can work in my fork and maybe sync them as they get more viable.

target_title: Clean up some warnings

note.body: Aisleriot is calling yelp by launching a "help:...." URI. I don't know if yelp's URI handler allows full paths in the URI ?

target_title: Can't add help file

note.body:
Workaround found::
Don't compile it with a --prefix= to my home folder. Use the system-wide default install.
It was running the system yelp from a private folder, which didn't have the new file. 
Is this a bug? Can it be made to run yelp with the --prefix= path from the private folder?

target_title: Can't add help file
Port to gtk4 and libadwaita

note.body:
> Has anyone started on this yet? I'd be willing to pick it up

Nobody. Go for it!

> Can we remove the Qt SVG code dependency?

It's possible modern librsvg can load and render the ksol card themes efficiently; haven't checked. If so, that could go; but anyway it's an optional dependency.

target_title: Port to gtk4 and libadwaita

note.body:
I looked at the codebase, and gosh are chunks of that code ancient. Here's a rough thought on how to approach it:

1. [ ] Get the code base to compile with GTK3 without deprecation/code warnings
1. [ ] Port to a more modern glib and librsvg coding style
    * Can we remove the Qt SVG code dependency?
1. [ ] Do a straight build with GTK4 with deprecated widgets
1. [ ] Drop deprecated widgets and use libadwaita

Along the way, there are some obvious cleanups that we should consider, such as using GSettings, add a test suite, clean up the UX, etc. I'd like to get as far along the way towards using GTK4/libadwaita before doing too many of those cleanups, though.

target_title: Port to gtk4 and libadwaita

note.body: (It could use a UI clean up as well)

target_title: Port to gtk4 and libadwaita

note.body: Has anyone started on this yet? I'd be willing to pick it up
